title: How to explain the potential difference

content.question: Four resistors are connected to a <math alttext="36 volt" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>36</mn><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mtext> </mtext><mi>V</mi></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> power supply, as shown above. The potential difference across the <math alttext="10 ohm" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>10</mn><mtext> </mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">Ω</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> resistor is <math alttext="4 volts" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>4</mn><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mtext> </mtext><mi>V</mi></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>. A student says that the potential difference across resistor <math alttext="R" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is <math alttext="32 volts" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mn>32</mn><mtext> </mtext><mi>V</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. Is the student correct, and why or why not?

choices.label: Yes. There is a loop that contains just <math alttext="R" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and the <math alttext="10 ohm" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>10</mn><mtext> </mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">Ω</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> resistor. The potential difference across <math alttext="R" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> plus that across the <math alttext="10 ohm" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>10</mn><mtext> </mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">Ω</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> resistor will equal the power supply <math alttext="e m f" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>e</mi><mi>m</mi><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. Therefore, the potential difference across resistor <math alttext="R" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is <math alttext="36 volts, minus, 4 volts, equals 32 volts" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>36</mn><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mtext> </mtext><mi>V</mi></mstyle><mo>−</mo><mn>4</mn><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mtext> </mtext><mi>V</mi></mstyle><mo>=</mo><mn>32</mn><mtext> </mtext><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mi>V</mi></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>.

No. The <math alttext="10 ohm" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>10</mn><mtext> </mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">Ω</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="6 ohm" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>6</mn><mtext> </mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">Ω</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> resistors are in parallel, so they have the same potential difference. There is a loop that contains <math alttext="R" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and both the <math alttext="10 ohm" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>10</mn><mtext> </mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">Ω</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="6 ohm" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>6</mn><mtext> </mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">Ω</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> resistors. So the potential difference across the <math alttext="10 ohm" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>10</mn><mtext> </mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">Ω</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> resistor plus that across the <math alttext="6 ohm" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>6</mn><mtext> </mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">Ω</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> resistor plus that across resistor <math alttext="R" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> will equal the power supply <math alttext="e m f" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>e</mi><mi>m</mi><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. Therefore, the potential difference across resistor <math alttext="R" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is <math alttext="36 volts, minus 4 volts, minus 4 volts, equals 28 volts" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>36</mn><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mtext> </mtext><mi>V</mi></mstyle><mo>−</mo><mn>4</mn><mtext> </mtext><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mi>V</mi></mstyle><mo>−</mo><mn>4</mn><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mtext> </mtext><mi>V</mi></mstyle><mo>=</mo><mn>28</mn><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mtext> </mtext><mi>V</mi></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>.

No. The <math alttext="10 ohm" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>10</mn><mtext> </mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">Ω</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="6 ohm" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>6</mn><mtext> </mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">Ω</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, and <math alttext="4 ohm" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>4</mn><mtext> </mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">Ω</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> resistors are in parallel, so they have the same potential difference. They are in series with resistor <math alttext="R" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, so the potential difference across each of the three parallel resistors plus that of resistor <math alttext="R" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> will equal the power supply <math alttext="e m f" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>e</mi><mi>m</mi><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. Therefore, the potential difference across resistor <math alttext="R" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is <math alttext="36 volts, minus 4 volts, minus 4 volts, minus 4 volts, equals 24 volts" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>36</mn><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mtext> </mtext><mi>V</mi></mrow></mstyle><mo>−</mo><mn>4</mn><mtext> </mtext><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>V</mi></mrow></mstyle><mo>−</mo><mn>4</mn><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mtext> </mtext><mi>V</mi></mrow></mstyle><mo>−</mo><mn>4</mn><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mtext> </mtext><mi>V</mi></mrow></mstyle><mo>=</mo><mn>24</mn><mtext> </mtext><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>V</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>.

No. All four resistors are in parallel, so they will all have the same potential difference. So the potential difference across <math alttext="R" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is equal to <math alttext="4 volts" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>4</mn><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mtext> </mtext><mi>V</mi></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>.

content.answer: Yes. There is a loop that contains just <math alttext="R" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and the <math alttext="10 ohm" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>10</mn><mtext> </mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">Ω</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> resistor. The potential difference across <math alttext="R" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> plus that across the <math alttext="10 ohm" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>10</mn><mtext> </mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">Ω</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> resistor will equal the power supply <math alttext="e m f" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>e</mi><mi>m</mi><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. Therefore, the potential difference across resistor <math alttext="R" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is <math alttext="36 volts, minus, 4 volts, equals 32 volts" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>36</mn><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mtext> </mtext><mi>V</mi></mstyle><mo>−</mo><mn>4</mn><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mtext> </mtext><mi>V</mi></mstyle><mo>=</mo><mn>32</mn><mtext> </mtext><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mi>V</mi></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>.

skill.text: 3.C: Justify or support a claim using evidence from experimental data, physical representations, or physical principles or laws.
